decision.summary: The extracted knowledge graph demonstrates correct overall structure with a complete causal-interventional pathway from risk through all six concept categories to intervention node. However, critical schema violations exist: missing required rationale fields (node_rationale, intervention_lifecycle_rationale, intervention_maturity_rationale, edge_rationale) on multiple nodes and edges, and undocumented 'embedding' fields violate schema. Two significant missing nodes represent gaps in coverage: author's explicit uncertainty about research goal alignment and the critical design principle requiring software/community enforcement of factored cognition behaviors. The intervention maturity is correctly identified as 1 (Foundational/Theoretical) due to author's stated low confidence, but confidence level of key motivating edge should be reduced from 2 to 1 based on source evidence of uncertainty. Referential integrity is sound, and no orphaned nodes exist. With proposed fixes applied, the fabric would achieve schema compliance and improved coverage of source content.

schema_check.issue: Node field 'embedding' present in schema but not defined in SCHEMA_REQUIREMENTS; should be removed or documented
schema_check.suggestion: Remove 'embedding' field from all nodes as it is not part of required schema

schema_check.issue: Edge field 'embedding' present in schema but not defined in SCHEMA_REQUIREMENTS; should be removed or documented
schema_check.suggestion: Remove 'embedding' field from all edges as it is not part of required schema

schema_check.issue: Intervention node 'Build and operate Fact Overflow platform for large-scale factored cognition experiments' has intervention_lifecycle=6 'Other', but lifecycle should be 1-5 for specific phases
schema_check.suggestion: Change to 1 (Model Design) as this is foundational system design, or 6 if 'Other' is intentional for cross-cutting initiatives

schema_check.issue: Intervention node missing 'intervention_lifecycle_rationale' and 'intervention_maturity_rationale' required attributes
schema_check.suggestion: Add both rationale fields with section title references from source

schema_check.issue: Several concept nodes missing 'node_rationale' attribute that explains why essential to fabric
schema_check.suggestion: Add node_rationale to all concept nodes with source section references

schema_check.issue: Edges missing 'edge_rationale' attribute explaining connection justification with section title reference
schema_check.suggestion: Add edge_rationale field to all edges with closest preceding data source section title

referential_check.issue: All edge source_node and target_node references match existing node names

rationale_mismatches.issue: Risk node focuses on 'slow progress in factored cognition research' but source emphasizes practical scalability and experiment acceleration rather than existential AI alignment risk framing
rationale_mismatches.evidence: From Benefits section: 'The feedback loop would be much tighter than with the weekly or bi-weekly experiments that Ought runs now. A tight feedback loop is great in many ways.'
rationale_mismatches.fix: Clarify risk as 'Limited experimental velocity in factored cognition research impedes hypothesis generation' - the actual risk is research inefficiency, not misalignment per se

rationale_mismatches.issue: Validation evidence node describes only feasibility estimates; source provides no empirical validation of the proposed system actually working
rationale_mismatches.evidence: Source states 'Quantifying these benefits is possible, but would take some weeks of modelling and talking with people. So far I'm not confident enough of the whole idea to make the effort.'
rationale_mismatches.fix: Recategorize as 'Design Rationale' or lower confidence validation since no actual validation study was conducted

rationale_mismatches.issue: Edge from validation evidence to intervention claims validation 'motivates' deployment, but source author expresses low confidence: 'I'm not confident of this exploration being useful at all'
rationale_mismatches.evidence: Abstract: 'I'm not confident of this exploration being useful at all. But at least I wrote it down.'
rationale_mismatches.fix: Reduce edge_confidence from 2 to 1, and add rationale noting author's explicit uncertainty

expected_edges_from_source.title: Tight feedback loop benefit from scaling
expected_edges_from_source.evidence: Benefits section: 'The feedback loop would be much tighter than with the weekly or bi-weekly experiments that Ought runs now. A tight feedback loop is great in many ways. For example, it would allow a researcher to test more hypotheses more often, more quickly and more cheaply.'
expected_source_node_name: Scaling factored cognition experiments tightens feedback loops and increases ML training data
expected_target_node_name: Creating large-scale online platform for factored cognition similar to Stack Overflow

expected_edges_from_source.title: ML training data generation benefit
expected_edges_from_source.evidence: Benefits section: 'It would generate a lot of data. These could be used as training data when we want to train an ML system to do factored cognition.'
expected_source_node_name: Scaling factored cognition experiments tightens feedback loops and increases ML training data
expected_target_node_name: Creating large-scale online platform for factored cognition similar to Stack Overflow

expected_edges_from_source.title: Development effort requirement
expected_edges_from_source.evidence: Feasibility section: 'Building Stack Overflow took five months from start of development to public beta. Then they spent a lot of time tweaking the system to make it more attractive and maintain quality. So I'd say building Fact Overflow would take five to fifteen months with a team of two to five people.'
expected_source_node_name: Feasibility modeling of development effort and user requirements based on Stack Overflow data
expected_target_node_name: Build and operate Fact Overflow platform for large-scale factored cognition experiments

expected_edges_from_source.title: User requirement calculation based on formula
expected_edges_from_source.evidence: Feasibility section formula n∗u=nw⋅na/(xc⋅xa⋅fa⋅tf) and Guesstimate model result: 'for tf=3h we need between 600 and 36 k users'
expected_source_node_name: Feasibility modeling of development effort and user requirements based on Stack Overflow data
expected_target_node_name: Build and operate Fact Overflow platform for large-scale factored cognition experiments

expected_edges_from_source.title: User retention and behavioral requirement
expected_edges_from_source.evidence: Feasibility section: 'Of course, the system would have to be useful and fun enough to retain that many users. As with Stack Overflow, the software and the community have to encourage and ensure that the users behave in a way that makes factored cognition work.'
expected_source_node_name: Need for community and software design to maintain quality behaviors
expected_target_node_name: Build and operate Fact Overflow platform for large-scale factored cognition experiments

expected_edges_from_source.title: Time to accumulate users based on Stack Exchange growth rates
expected_edges_from_source.evidence: Feasibility section: 'Assume that it takes Fact Overflow twice as long as Stack Overflow to reach a certain number of sign-ups. Then it would take one month to reach 700 sign-ups and twenty-two months to reach 42 k sign-ups.'
expected_source_node_name: Feasibility modeling of development effort and user requirements based on Stack Overflow data
expected_target_node_name: Build and operate Fact Overflow platform for large-scale factored cognition experiments

expected_edges_from_source.title: Author uncertainty about utility
expected_edges_from_source.evidence: Abstract: 'I'm not confident of this exploration being useful at all. But at least I wrote it down.' And Benefits section: 'Note that I might be misunderstanding the goals and constraints of Ought's experiments. In that case this benefit might be irrelevant.'
expected_source_node_name: Conceptual uncertainty about Ought's research goals and constraints
expected_target_node_name: Scaling factored cognition experiments tightens feedback loops and increases ML training data

change_node_fields.node_name: Build and operate Fact Overflow platform for large-scale factored cognition experiments
change_node_fields.json_new_value: "Lifecycle 6 (Other) because this is a foundational infrastructure initiative that spans multiple phases: design (1), implementation (2-3), testing (4), and deployment (5). Per Feasibility section: requires '2-5 person team', '5-15 months' development, and 'one to twenty-two months' user recruitment. Classified as cross-cutting system work rather than single-phase intervention."

change_node_fields.node_name: Build and operate Fact Overflow platform for large-scale factored cognition experiments

Feasibility analysis is rough estimation ('sloppy and probably overconfident' per source) with no proof-of-concept implementation. Per Feasibility: 'The estimates are sloppy and probably overconfident.'"

Community and software design enabling factored cognition user behavior in large-scale systems

nodes.name: Slow progress in factored cognition research for AI alignment
nodes.description: Difficulty in developing factored cognition techniques quickly enough to contribute to AI alignment efforts, risking misaligned AI systems.

nodes.name: Limited scale of factored cognition experiments at Ought
nodes.description: Current experiments involve few users and weekly/bi-weekly cycles, restricting hypothesis testing and data generation.
aliases: restricted participant numbers in Ought studies

nodes.name: Scaling factored cognition experiments tightens feedback loops and increases ML training data
nodes.description: Hypothesis that many simultaneous users would allow root questions to be solved within hours and create sizeable datasets for machine learning.
aliases: greater scale yields more data for training

nodes.name: Creating large-scale online platform for factored cognition similar to Stack Overflow
nodes.description: Design idea to host many concurrent workspace trees, leveraging community Q&A dynamics to support factored cognition workflows.

nodes.name: Fact Overflow system with workspace trees and user action workflow
nodes.description: Implementation concept: users work on isolated workspaces in a tree, with parameters like contamination factor and action frequency governing quality.

nodes.name: Feasibility modeling of development effort and user requirements based on Stack Overflow data
nodes.description: Rough estimates: 5–15 months development with 2–5 people; 600–36k users needed to finish a question tree in 3 h; 1–22 months to recruit users.

nodes.name: Build and operate Fact Overflow platform for large-scale factored cognition experiments
nodes.description: Action: allocate a 2–5 person team to develop a Stack-Overflow-like site supporting workspace trees, then recruit 600–36k active users to run 24/7 factored cognition experiments.

notes: BLOCKER 1: Schema violations - missing node_rationale field on all concept nodes [0-5]. Source evidence: SCHEMA_REQUIREMENTS specify 'node_rationale: why essential to fabric with closest preceding data source section title reference' but extraction provides zero instances.

BLOCKER 2: All edges missing required edge_rationale field. Schema specifies 'edge_rationale: connection justification with closest preceding data source section title reference' but extraction provides zero instances.
BLOCKER 3: Intervention node missing intervention_lifecycle_rationale and intervention_maturity_rationale. Both are required per output format specification.

COVERAGE GAP 1: Author explicitly questions goal alignment. Source Benefits section: 'Note that I might be misunderstanding the goals and constraints of Ought's experiments. In that case this benefit might be irrelevant.' This assumption uncertainty is missing as node, which is critical foundation for entire reasoning path.

COVERAGE GAP 2: Design principle for community behavior not captured. Source Feasibility: 'the software and the community have to encourage and ensure that the users behave in a way that makes factored cognition work' - this is essential design requirement missing from implementation mechanism node.

CONFIDENCE CALIBRATION: Edge from validation evidence (feasibility modeling) to intervention should be confidence 1, not 2. Source Abstract: 'I'm not confident of this exploration being useful at all. But at least I wrote it down.' and Feasibility: 'The estimates are sloppy and probably overconfident.' This is explicit author uncertainty requiring lowest confidence.
REFERENTIAL INTEGRITY: PASS - all 6 edges reference existing nodes with exact name matches. No dangling references detected.
ORPHAN CHECK: PASS - all 7 nodes connect to fabric through edges. Node connection structure forms complete path risk→problem→insight→design→mechanism→validation→intervention with no isolated nodes.
DUPLICATES: PASS - no duplicate nodes or edges detected. Node names are appropriately granular and non-overlapping.
LIFECYCLE CLASSIFICATION: Intervention lifecycle=6 'Other' is defensible for foundational infrastructure initiative spanning multiple phases (design through deployment) over 5-15 months per source.
SCHEMA COMPLIANCE: 'embedding' field present in extracted JSON but not part of SCHEMA_REQUIREMENTS. This violates schema definition and should be removed from all nodes/edges.
